docs.title: Meet Vincent Vango
docs.text:
This is my 2020 Ford Transit I purchased used via an auction here in Colorado. It was a Penske truck in its previous life. The van was a little scraped and dinged up when I picked it up but it was fleet maintained during the first four years of life.

Specs:

  • 2020 Ford Transit T-250
  • 3.5L PFDI V6 engine producing 275HP
  • Rear Wheel Drive
  • Mileage: 100,896 as of April 1st, 2024

These are my notes as I baseline and build out the van for weekend adventuring, my remote office and using as a utility vehicle.

docs.title: 80/20 DIY Roof Rack
docs.text: Instead of spending big bucks on a full blown rack solution I found these aluminum brackets on https://diyvan.com for mounting 80/20 extruded aluminum for solar panels.

docs.title: About
docs.text:
Hey I'm Casey and I guess I am a little obsessed with camping inside the vehicles that I own. There are a lot of great places to get outside in Colorado and being able to basecamp out of your vehicle makes those places a lot more fun to visit.

I think when I really got the bug for car camping was this trip to Moab, Utah camping out of a Mitsubishi Delica I imported from Japan.

This gradually evolved into bed setup in the back of my 1996 Toyota Landcruiser Prado with a roof rack on top.

Now I have graduated to a high roof van that I (6'2") can stand up inside! 🙌

docs.title: Removing the bulk head
docs.text:
My van was a delivery van during its first life and came with a metal bulk head. First order of business was to remove the bulk head to open up the space and make way for installing the seat swivels

It was mainly a lot of 11mm bolts that I made quick work of with my impact

Full view of the front, very tight against the seats

Removal of half the bulk head

Had to remove the floor piece that was screwed in with riv-nuts that ended up being rusty.

Completely removed, so much more room for activites!

Next up, dealing with the rust I found on the floor. > Rusty Floor Mitigation

docs.title: Thinsulate Headliner
docs.text:
There is a large space above the headliner in the front of the van that is a great place to start insulating. Here are the steps to loosen the headliner

Start by removing the two bolts in each handle above the driver and passenger seats

There are large cavities on either side of the headliner that need to be filled

Remove the three clips in the center of the headliner so it can be lowered

There are large cavities on either side of the headliner that need to be filled

I measured and cut the thinsulation and started sliding it down into the edge of the windshield

Once the insulation was tucked in I buttoned it all back into place

Next up, insulating the sliding rear door. > Sliding Door Insulation

docs.title: Rusty floor mitigation
docs.text:
Whoever installed the bulk head did absolutely nothing to waterproof or seal the holes so moisture crept through the fasteners and soaked through the protective mat in the back of the Transit. Here is the process of mitigating the rust before laying down flooring.

This was after a light pass of sanding and scraping, fortunately it's just surface rust

I ended up using evaporust on the floor and that helped convert a lot of the rust

At the auto parts store I discovered heavy sanding discs for paint removal and that really sped up the process of getting to bare metal

Here's a shot of the medium sanding disc attached to the end of my drill

I laid down several thin layers of Rustoleum self-etching primer after cleaning the surface

Here it is after four coats of primer, starting to look better

Finally I laid down several coats of Rustoleum Automotive enamel paint

Next up, replacing the raggidty radio antenna. > Stubby Antenna

docs.title: Thinsulate sidewalls and back doors
docs.text:
I found kitchen shears to be the best tool to use for cutting the 3M SM600L Acoustic and Thermal Insulation. And 3M Super 77 spray adhesive on the van door allowing 30 seconds to get tacky I could just stick the insulation directly to the door.

Using the plastic corregated panels that came with the van made measuring the SM600L insulation easy to do on my living room floor. You can see I taped Low-E Reflective Insulation on the backs of each of the panels

Here's a fully stuffed sidewall of the van ready to be hidden behind a plastic corregated panel

Next up, constructing an inexpensive roof rack > 80/20 Roof Rack

docs.title: Thinsulate Sliding Door
docs.text:
After popping off the plastic clips to the door, the plastic sheeting needed to be removed. If you slowly pull on the edges you can remove the rubber gasket material will peel with the plastic sheet

This is what the sliding door looks like after removing the plastic sheeting

I tucked the thinsulate behind the cabling in the door having to cut little slits to get around the metal studs in the door

I used the corrugated plastic sheeting as a template to cut the thinsulate

I tucked the thinsulate behind the cabling in the door having to cut little slits to get around the metal studs in the door

Here's what the finished door looks like after tucking in all insulation

Next up, installing insulation in the back doors and sidewalls. > Sidewall Insulation

docs.title: Stubby Antenna Install
docs.text:
The van came with a factory antenna that had the coating unraveling and looked pretty junky so I found a stubby antenna to install and it looks a lot more sleek now.

Next up, starting to insulate the van. > Headliner Insulation
